title: Eight Colombian Microenterprises and One Microfinance Institution Win Citi Awards
summary: Bogotá, Colombia - Eight Colombian microentrepreneurs and one microfinance institution were honored in the 14th Annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, which aim to underscore the contributions of microfinance organizations, business training centers and chambers of commerce to the sector, as well as the importance of entrepreneurial projects around the country.
tag-1: Eight Colombian Microenterprises and One Microfinance Institution Win Citi Awards
tag-3: Bogotá, Colombia – Eight Colombian microentrepreneurs and one microfinance institution were honored in the 14th Annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, which aim to underscore the contributions of microfinance organizations, business training centers and chambers of commerce to the sector, as well as the importance of entrepreneurial projects around the country.
tag-4: The winners were selected from among 214 plus nominees from 24 provinces whose projects were evaluated by a team of 38 Citi Colombia volunteers.
tag-5: "Year after year, the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards convene relevant public and private sector actors who play a role in the development of a microfinance network in Colombia," commented Juliana Álvarez, Director of the Investment Banking Opportunities Program and a member of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards judging committee. "The resulting synergies facilitate knowledge sharing and, most important, bring us closer to the direct beneficiaries of these financial instruments, their personal stories and the stories of their businesses. Their projects serve as examples for others to emulate and show the value of taking advantage of microloans."
tag-6: This year's award included three new categories relevant to the Colombian context: Young Entrepreneurs, a reflection of Citi's commitment to preparing young people to succeed in today's economy; Agriculture and Livestock, which recognizes the contributions of this sector in promoting rural microfinance; and Environmental Management, an existing award category that is being emphasized more strongly this year to showcase initiatives dedicated to environmental sustainability and conservation.
tag-7: "The Citi Foundation Citi has been an active partner in strengthening microfinance in this country and acknowledging the sector's importance in achieving progress for Colombians. These awards, along with other Foundation-sponsored initiatives, are helping to perfect the tools the microfinance system has to offer and give more Colombians access to microcredit," María Clara Hoyos, President of Asomicrofinanzas, remarked.
tag-8: In the category of Production, first prize went to Carlos Darío Marín Chavarriaga and his microenterprise, Pradera Verde EU, dedicated to the organic processing of Andean-Amazonian fruit from Valle de Sibundoy, Putumayo.
tag-9: Juan Felipe Jaimes of Medellín won top honors in the Commerce and Services category for AndianLink, a specialty coffee distributor. First place in Agriculture and Livestock went to Andrés Tarapues of Cumbal, Nariño province, for Caviasur, a company that commercializes the meat of guinea pigs, a traditional food.
tag-10: The winner of the Environmental Management award was Mildred Alejandra Ortiz, whose ecotourism outfit, Centro Ecoturístico Amazónico Paway, in Mocoa, Putumayo, educates visitors about the biodiversity of this rainforest region, promoting sustainability and green business practices.
tag-11: Young Entrepreneur of the year was Francisco Sepúlveda of Pasto, Nariño. His microenterprise, XZAE S.A.S, designs and makes clothing using industrial and artisanal techniques that reflect local culture.
tag-12: The award for Most Innovative Microfinance Institution went to Actuar Quindío, whose "Empresarios S.O.S." program provides personalized business advice to microentrepreneurs to help them overcome difficult financial situations, increase their payment commitment and improve their business skills.
tag-13: Finally, the winner of the award for Communal Banking was Asociación Asopraduce of San Basilio de Palenque, Bolívar. The association produces and commercializes traditional sweets from the region made with local products such as peanuts, cassava, coconut, guava and sesame.
tag-14: "This version of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards is very special, coinciding as it does with the celebration of Citi's first 100 years in Colombia. As part of our commitment to contribute to progress, the awards have enabled us to support more than 100 microenterprises over the last 14 years, helping them strengthen the management and financial capabilities they need to grow," said Bernardo Chacín, Citi's President for Colombia and the Andean Region.
tag-15: Citi awarded a total of $195 million pesos to the award winners, who also received a day of financial intelligence and business skills training led by Emprender and recognition at the awards ceremony held this morning at the JW Marriott hotel in Bogotá. Participants at the ceremony acknowledged Citi's commitment to microfinance as a tool for economic empowerment and financial inclusion at the community level.
tag-16: "The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards are a platform that supports the entrepreneurial sector in Colombia by motivating entrepreneurs to keep on dreaming," commented July Astrid Ardila, Director of Emprender. "The awards encourage new business creation and environmental best practices, and they recognize our country's productive and cultural capital as reflected in the stories of men and women who create new initiatives and believe in building a better future for their families and communities."
